text: fixed formula fixed effects, multiple responses passed matrix using cbind random formula random effects. Multiple random terms can passed using + operator, general case random term form variance.function(formula):linking.function(random.terms). Currently, variance.functions available idv, idh, us, cor[] ante[]. idv fits constant variance across components formula. idh us fit different variances across component formula, us also fit covariances. corg fixes variances along diagonal one corgh fixes variances along diagonal specified prior.  cors allows correlation submatrices. ante[] fits ante-dependence structures different order (e.g ante1, ante2), number can prefixed c hold regression coefficients order equal. number can also suffixed v hold innovation variances equal (e.g antec2v 3 parameters).  formula can contain factors numeric terms (.e. random regression) although noted intercept term suppressed.  (co)variances (co)variances random.terms effects.  Currently, linking.functions available mm str. mm fits multimembership model multiple random terms separated + operator. str allows covariances exist multiple random terms also separated + operator. cases levels multiple random terms .  simpler models variance.function(formula) linking.function(random.terms) can omitted model syntax simpler form ~random1+random2+....  two reserved variables: units index rows response variable trait index columns response variable rcov formula residual covariance structure. set data point associated unique residual. example multi-response model might R-structure defined ~us(trait):units family optional character vector trait distributions. Currently, "gaussian", "poisson",  "categorical", "multinomial",  "ordinal", "threshold", "exponential", "geometric", "cengaussian", "cenpoisson",  "cenexponential",  "zipoisson", "zapoisson", "ztpoisson", "hupoisson", "zibinomial", "threshold", "nzbinom" , "ncst", "msst" , "hubinomial", "ztmb" "ztmultinomial" supported, prefix "cen" means censored, prefix "zi" means zero inflated, prefix "za" means zero altered, prefix "zt" means zero truncated prefix "hu" means hurdle. NULL, data needs contain family column. mev optional vector measurement error variances data point random effect meta-analysis. data data.frame start optional list 5 possible elements: R (R-structure) G (G-structure) Liab (latent variables liabilities) contain starting values G also list many elements random effect components. element QUASI logical: TRUE starting latent variables obtained heuristically, FALSE sampled Z-distribution. element r -1 1 determines correlation starting latent variables ordered latent variables (ordered response variable): default 0.8. prior optional list prior specifications 4 possible elements: R (R-structure) G (G-structure), B (fixed effects) S (theta_scale parameter). B S lists containing expected value (mu) (co)variance matrix (V) representing strength belief: defaults B$mu=S$mu=0 B$V=S$V=*1e+10, identity matrix appropriate dimension.  priors variance structures (R G) lists expected (co)variances (V) degree belief parameter (nu) inverse-Wishart (note parameterisation non-standard - see rIW), also mean vector (alpha.mu) covariance matrix (alpha.V) redundant working parameters. defaults nu=0, V=1, alpha.mu=0, alpha.V=0. alpha.V non-zero, parameter expanded algorithms used. tune optional list elements mh_V /mh_weights mh_V list many elements R-structure terms element (co)variance matrix defining proposal distribution associated latent variables. NULL adaptive algorithm used ceases adapt burn-phase finished. mh_weights equal number latent variables acts scaling factor proposal standard deviations. pedigree ordered pedigree 3 columns id, dam sire phylo object. argument retained back compatibility - see ginverse argument general formulation. nodes pedigree/phylogeny nodes estimated. default, "" estimates effects individuals pedigree nodes phylogeny (including ancestral nodes). phylogenies "TIPS" estimates effects tips , pedigrees vector ids can passed nodes specifying subset individuals animal effects estimated.  Note analyses equivalent omitted nodes missing data absorbing nodes chain max mix better. However, algorithm may less numerically stable may iterate slower, especially large phylogenies. scale logical: phylogeny (needs ultrametric) scaled unit length (distance root tip)? nitt number MCMC iterations thin thinning interval burnin burnin pr logical: posterior distribution random effects saved? pl logical: posterior distribution latent variables saved? verbose logical: TRUE MH diagnostics printed screen DIC logical: TRUE deviance deviance information criterion calculated singular.ok logical: FALSE linear dependencies fixed effects removed. TRUE left estimated, although information comes form prior saveX logical: save fixed effect design matrix saveZ logical: save random effect design matrix saveXL logical: save structural parameter design matrix slice logical: slice sampling used? applicable binary traits independent residuals ginverse list sparse inverse matrices (\({\bf ^{-1}}\)) proportional covariance structure random effects. names matrices correspond columns data associated random term. levels random term appear rownames matrices. trunc logical: latent variables binary models truncated prevent /overflow (+/-20 categorical/multinomial models +/-7 threshold/probit models)? theta_scale optional list 4 possible elements specifying set location effects (fixed random) scaled parameter theta_scale subset observations level level factor factor: factor, level, fixed (position fixed terms scaled) random (position random effect components). saveWS logical: save design matrix scaled effects. aggregate character: names long-format variables formed wide-format variables multi-trait models. Wide-format variables long-format variable name followed underscore trait name. example, wide-format data frame might variable names y1, y2, x_y1, x_y2. multi-trait model fitted y1 y2 aggregate="x" generates new variable x=c(x_y1, x_y2)).

title: Multivariate Generalised Linear Mixed Models — MCMCglmm
code: # Example 1: univariate Gaussian model with standard random effect   data(PlodiaPO)   model1<-MCMCglmm(PO~1, random=~FSfamily, data=PlodiaPO, verbose=FALSE,  nitt=1300, burnin=300, thin=1) summary(model1) #>  #>  Iterations = 301:1300 #>  Thinning interval  = 1 #>  Sample size  = 1000  #>  #>  DIC: -239.78  #>  #>  G-structure:  ~FSfamily #>  #>          post.mean l-95% CI u-95% CI eff.samp #> FSfamily   0.01027 0.005385  0.01579    414.1 #>  #>  R-structure:  ~units #>  #>       post.mean l-95% CI u-95% CI eff.samp #> units    0.0341  0.02966  0.03843    826.9 #>  #>  Location effects: PO ~ 1  #>  #>             post.mean l-95% CI u-95% CI eff.samp  pMCMC     #> (Intercept)     1.163    1.132    1.195     1463 <0.001 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1  # Example 2: univariate Gaussian model with phylogenetically correlated # random effect  data(bird.families)   phylo.effect<-rbv(bird.families, 1, nodes="TIPS")  phenotype<-phylo.effect+rnorm(dim(phylo.effect)[1], 0, 1)    # simulate phylogenetic and residual effects with unit variance  test.data<-data.frame(phenotype=phenotype, taxon=row.names(phenotype))  Ainv<-inverseA(bird.families)$Ainv  # inverse matrix of shared phyloegnetic history  prior<-list(R=list(V=1, nu=0.002), G=list(G1=list(V=1, nu=0.002)))  model2<-MCMCglmm(phenotype~1, random=~taxon, ginverse=list(taxon=Ainv),  data=test.data, prior=prior, verbose=FALSE, nitt=1300, burnin=300, thin=1)  plot(model2$VCV)

what: Multivariate Generalised Linear Mixed Models — MCMCglmm-package
title: Multivariate Generalised Linear Mixed Models — MCMCglmm-package
text: MCMCglmm package fitting Generalised Linear Mixed Models using Markov chain Monte Carlo techniques (Hadfield 2009). commonly used distributions like normal Poisson supported together useful less popular ones like zero-inflated Poisson multinomial. Missing values left, right interval censoring accommodated traits. package also supports multi-trait models multiple responses can follow different types distribution.  package allows various residual random-effect variance structures specified including heterogeneous variances, unstructured covariance matrices random regression (e.g. random slope models).  Three special types variance structure can specified associated pedigrees (animal models), phylogenies (comparative method) measurement error (meta-analysis). package makes heavy use results Sorensen & Gianola (2002) Davis (2006) taken together result hopefully fast efficient routine. small medium sized problems take seconds minutes, large problems (> 20,000 records) possible.  interest evolutionary biology also several functions applying Rice's (2004) tensor analysis real data functions visualising comparing matrices. Please read tutorial vignette("Tutorial", "MCMCglmm") course notes  vignette("CourseNotes", "MCMCglmm")

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ x<-rnorm(100) y<-x^2+cos(x)-x+0.2*x^3+rnorm(100) plot(y~x) lines((x^2+cos(x)-x+0.2*x^3)[order(x)]~sort(x))  dat<-data.frame(y=y, x=x)  m1<-MCMCglmm(y~x, random=~idv(spl(x)), data=dat, pr=TRUE, verbose=FALSE) # penalised smoother m2<-MCMCglmm(y~x+spl(x),data=dat,  verbose=FALSE)                        # non-penalised  pred1<-(cbind(m1$X,m1$Z)%*%colMeans(m1$Sol))@x pred2<-(cbind(m2$X)%*%colMeans(m2$Sol))@x  lines(pred1[order(x)]~sort(x), col="red") lines(pred2[order(x)]~sort(x), col="green")  m1$DIC-mean(m1$Deviance)  # effective number of parameters < 13 m2$DIC-mean(m2$Deviance)  # effective number of parameters ~ 13 } # }
